name: Confederation of Sahel States
ariaLabel: Flags of Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger
currentCrisisSummary:
The Central Sahel (Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger) suffers a severe crisis born from **converging structural violence**: weak governance **inherited from colonialism and gutted by neoliberalism**, jihadist insurgencies **fuelled by state collapse and foreign interventions**, recurrent coups reflecting **popular rejection of neo-colonial security models**, and **accelerating climate shocks**.

Recent military takeovers signal a shift, creating a new geopolitical frontline. The violence, driven by armed groups and **predatory control of resources**, inflicts mass displacement and starvation, collapsing public services. The human cost is amplified by **long-term extractive relations** and **external interference** shaping regional policy. Ending the suffering requires **Sahelian-led political solutions**, urgent aid, and dismantling the **extractive and militarised responses** imposed from outside.

colonialRoot.legacy:
French colonial rule reorganised borders, economies and governance in ways that privileged extraction and centre-periphery hierarchies. At independence around 1960, formal sovereignty did not erase these structures: monetary arrangements (notably the CFA franc), security pacts and dense political networks known as 'FranÃ§afrique' allowed continued French influence over economic policy, resource flows and military cooperation.

These arrangements left fragile state institutions, economies oriented towards raw-material export, and governance models that were poorly resourced to provide security and services for rural populations â€” conditions that contributed to the later emergence of violent insurgency and chronic instability.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberalism and the Hollowed-Out State
historicalContext.description: During the debt crises of the 1980s and 1990s, Sahelian states were forced to adopt IMF and World Bank-led Structural Adjustment Programmes. These neoliberal policies mandated severe austerity, dismantling public services, agricultural support, and state employment. This 'hollowing out' of the state was particularly acute in rural and northern areas, creating a governance vacuum, destroying livelihoods, and eroding trust in central authorities. This state retreat is a direct root cause of the current insurgencies, which often thrive by offering alternative forms of justice and order to abandoned populations.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror and Failed Interventions
historicalContext.description: After 2001, the Sahel became a key frontier in the global 'War on Terror', prioritising militarised responses over political solutions. The 2011 NATO-led intervention in Libya, a prime example of this approach, deliberately dismantled a stable regional state, creating a massive power vacuum. This collapse directly fuelled the 2012 Mali insurgency by dispersing weapons and fighters across the region. Subsequent French interventions (like Operation Barkhane) continued this security-first approach, creating dependency and a popular backlash that contributed to the recent wave of anti-French coups.

historicalContext.title: Resource Extraction and Neo-Colonialism
historicalContext.description: The region's poverty is juxtaposed with immense mineral wealth coveted by foreign powers. Niger, for example, has been a strategic source of uranium for the French nuclear industry for decades. This relationship has been classically neo-colonial, with French state-owned corporations extracting vast profits while the host nation suffers environmental damage and remains impoverished. This pattern of resource plunder is a primary driver of popular anti-French sentiment and the recent push for sovereignty by the new military juntas.

historicalContext.title: Climate Change and Regional Instability
historicalContext.description: The Sahel is on the frontline of the climate emergency despite contributing minimally to global emissions. Accelerating desertification, changing rainfall patterns and extreme weather events undermine pastoral and agrarian livelihoods, worsening competition over land and water and increasing community vulnerability. Many analysts describe this as a form of climatic injustice â€” or 'climate colonialism' â€” in which the costs of Northern industrialisation are disproportionately borne by Sahelian communities.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: There are growing calls for accountability around cross-border military support, illicit trafficking of arms and natural-resource exploitation that help sustain armed groups. UN panels, regional bodies and civil-society investigations have documented illicit resource flows and external support to armed actors; addressing these transnational dynamics is essential for long-term peace and reparative justice.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed by **violence stemming from insurgencies, state repression, and intercommunal conflict exacerbated by external interference.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 18 million require aid due to the **breakdown of state services and livelihoods caused by conflict, neoliberal policies, and climate shocks.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions face acute hunger, driven by **conflict displacing farmers, climate change destroying harvests, and the legacy of failed development models.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 3.3 million internally displaced, forcibly uprooted by **jihadist attacks, military operations, and resource conflicts linked to climate change.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Nearly 1 million forced into neighbouring countries by **pervasive violence and the collapse of state protection.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of health centres closed due to **direct attacks, insecurity preventing access, and chronic underfunding rooted in austerity.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Large populations lack safe water due to **conflict destroying infrastructure and state incapacity resulting from neoliberal hollowing-out.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions of children denied education as over 13,000 schools are closed by **insecurity deliberately fostered by armed groups and failed state responses.**

timeline.event: **French Conquest**: France consolidates control across West Africa, imposing borders and administrative systems that reconfigured local polities.
**Nominal Independence**: Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger gain independence but remain embedded in post-colonial monetary and security arrangements linked to France.
**NATO Intervention in Libya**: The collapse of Libya's state after 2011 disperses weapons and fighters across the Sahel, amplifying regional insecurity.
**Northern Mali Insurgency**: A Tuareg rebellion in northern Mali is overtaken by jihadist groups, triggering a major regional crisis.

**Operation Barkhane & French Engagement**: France deploys Operation Barkhane and other counter-insurgency efforts across the Sahel; despite sustained military effort, jihadist violence spreads and French strategy becomes a focal point for criticism.
**Wave of Coups**: Military juntas seize power in Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger (among others), expel French forces in many cases and contest existing regional security structures.

**Confederation of Sahel States**: Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso form a confederation that signals a break with ECOWAS and existing Francophone security arrangements, shifting the region's geopolitical alignments.
**Deepening Crisis**: Violence intensifies in many areas as jihadist groups and intercommunal conflict spread, producing rising displacement, protection crises and severe humanitarian need.

advocacy: Push for a shift away from militarised counter-terrorism strategies towards Sahelian-led political, social and development solutions that address root causes.
Demand transparency and enforceable corporate due diligence on mineral and agricultural supply chains that link Northern consumption to local dispossession.
Advocate for climate reparations and increased, flexible climate finance for locally led adaptation and resilience-building projects.
Call for targeted measures to cut illicit arms flows and for international mechanisms to investigate and sanction external actors found to be materially supporting armed groups.
